**Mandalay Bay** is a 43-story luxury [resort](/wiki/Resort "Resort") and
[casino](/wiki/Casino "Casino") on the [Las Vegas Strip](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Strip
"Las Vegas Strip") in [Paradise](/wiki/Paradise,_Nevada "Paradise, Nevada"),
[Nevada](/wiki/Nevada "Nevada"). It is owned and operated by [MGM Resorts
International](/wiki/MGM_Resorts_International "MGM Resorts International").
One of the property's towers operates as the [Delano](/wiki/Delano_Las_Vegas
"Delano Las Vegas"); the [Four Seasons Hotel](/wiki/Four_Seasons_Hotel "Four
Seasons Hotel") is independently operated within the Mandalay Bay tower,
occupying 5 floors (35–39).

Mandalay Bay has 3,309 hotel rooms, 24 elevators and a casino of 135,000
square feet (12,500 m2). Adjacent to the hotel is the 2,000,000 square feet
(190,000 m2) [Mandalay Bay Convention
Center](/wiki/Mandalay_Bay_Convention_Center "Mandalay Bay Convention Center")
and the 12,000-seat [Mandalay Bay Events
Center](/wiki/Mandalay_Bay_Events_Center "Mandalay Bay Events Center"). The
[Mandalay Bay Tram](/wiki/Mandalay_Bay_Tram "Mandalay Bay Tram") connects the
resort to its sister properties, [Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur_Hotel_and_Casino
"Excalibur Hotel and Casino") and [Luxor](/wiki/Luxor_Hotel "Luxor Hotel"),
all three of which were constructed by [Circus Circus
Enterprises](/wiki/Circus_Circus_Enterprises "Circus Circus Enterprises")
before its sale to MGM.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mandalay_Bay&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/View_from_Mandalay_Bay_Hotel.jpg/220px-
View_from_Mandalay_Bay_Hotel.jpg)](/wiki/File:View_from_Mandalay_Bay_Hotel.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:View_from_Mandalay_Bay_Hotel.jpg "Enlarge")

View from Mandalay Bay hotel looking north (2014)

In 1995, [Circus Circus Enterprises](/wiki/Circus_Circus_Enterprises "Circus
Circus Enterprises") bought the [Hacienda](/wiki/Hacienda_\(resort\) "Hacienda
\(resort\)") for $80 million and an adjacent 74-acre (30 ha) site for $73
million.[1] They closed the Hacienda on December 1, 1996, and imploded it a
month later on [New Year's Eve](/wiki/New_Year%27s_Eve "New Year's
Eve").[2][3] Plans for the tropical-themed "Project Paradise" were revealed
the same day, with an estimated budget of $800 million to $1 billion.[4] In
February 1998 the project was renamed Mandalay Bay to evoke the exotic
tropical romanticism of the poem "[Mandalay](/wiki/Mandalay_\(poem\) "Mandalay
\(poem\)")".[5]

Problems arose during construction because of excessive and uneven settling of
the soil beneath the building; the core of the building sank by 17 inches (430
mm), while one of the wings had settled by only 2 inches (51 mm).[6][7] Rumors
about the severity of the issues depressed Circus Circus's stock price.[6] The
problem was solved by installing 536 micropiles (200-foot-long metal pipes
filled with [grout](/wiki/Grout "Grout"), each capped with a [hydraulic
jack](/wiki/Hydraulic_jack "Hydraulic jack")) below the building, at an
estimated cost of $8 to $10 million.[6][8][9]

The resort opened on March 2, 1999, with grand opening festivities that
included the [Blues Brothers](/wiki/Blues_Brothers "Blues Brothers") ([Dan
Aykroyd](/wiki/Dan_Aykroyd "Dan Aykroyd"), [James Belushi](/wiki/James_Belushi
"James Belushi"), and [John Goodman](/wiki/John_Goodman "John Goodman"))
leading a procession of 200 motorcycles to Mandalay Bay's front doors, and a
concert by [Bob Dylan](/wiki/Bob_Dylan "Bob Dylan") at the House of
Blues.[10][11]

In June 1999, Circus Circus changed its name to Mandalay Resort Group.[12]

Construction of a major convention center at Mandalay Bay was begun in June
2001, with its opening originally set for the summer of 2002.[13][14] After a
delay in the wake of the [September 11, 2001](/wiki/September_11,_2001
"September 11, 2001") attacks, the [Mandalay Bay Convention
Center](/wiki/Mandalay_Bay_Convention_Center "Mandalay Bay Convention Center")
opened in January 2003.[15][16] With 1.5 million square feet (140,000 m2) of
space, it was the fifth largest convention center in the nation.[17]

On May 23, 2002, the Mandalay Resort Group announced a second 1,122-room hotel
tower, with a cost of at least $200 million.[18] Construction began on the
project in September 2002. The name of the tower, [THEhotel at Mandalay
Bay](/wiki/THEhotel_at_Mandalay_Bay "THEhotel at Mandalay Bay"), was revealed
in October 2003.[19] The tower opened on December 17, 2003.[20]

In February 2005, Mandalay Resort Group was sold to [MGM
Mirage](/wiki/MGM_Mirage "MGM Mirage") (later MGM Resorts International), who
currently own the resort. The acquisition was finalized on April 25, 2005.

### 2017 shooting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mandalay_Bay&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: 2017 shooting")]

Main article: [2017 Las Vegas shooting](/wiki/2017_Las_Vegas_shooting "2017
Las Vegas shooting")

On October 1, 2017, gunman [Stephen Paddock](/wiki/Stephen_Paddock "Stephen
Paddock") opened fire on an [adjacent country music
festival](/wiki/Route_91_Harvest "Route 91 Harvest") from a room on the 32nd
floor of the hotel, killing 58 and wounding 546. The shooting ended when
Paddock committed suicide before [Las Vegas Metropolitan Police
Department](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Metropolitan_Police_Department "Las Vegas
Metropolitan Police Department") officers breached the hotel room.[21][22][23]
The incident is the deadliest mass shooting by a lone gunman in recent U.S.
history.[24]

## Hotels[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mandalay_Bay&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Hotels")]

### Penthouse
suites[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mandalay_Bay&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Penthouse suites")]

The gold coloring of the hotel is a result of gold leaf used on the windows.
Levels 40-42 (numbered as floors 60–62) are designed as penthouse suites, with
a penthouse lounge on level 62 for guests staying in the
penthouses.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Level 43 (numbered as 64) is the Foundation
Room, a restaurant and bar.[25]

### Four Seasons
Hotel[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mandalay_Bay&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Four Seasons Hotel")]

Five floors (floors 35–39) of the main hotel building are occupied by the
five-star and [AAA](/wiki/American_Automobile_Association "American Automobile
Association") Five-Diamond [Four Seasons Hotel](/wiki/Four_Seasons_Hotel "Four
Seasons Hotel") Las Vegas.[26]

### Delano Las Vegas (adjacent
building)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mandalay_Bay&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Delano Las Vegas \(adjacent building\)")]

Main article: [Delano Las Vegas](/wiki/Delano_Las_Vegas "Delano Las Vegas")

The resort's second tower, with 45 stories and 1,117 suites, previously
operated as THEhotel at Mandalay Bay, now operates as Delano Las Vegas. Each
suite is at least 750 square feet (70 m2).

## Attractions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mandalay_Bay&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Attractions")]

### Shows[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mandalay_Bay&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Shows")]

A production of the classic Broadway musical
_[Chicago](/wiki/Chicago_\(musical\) "Chicago \(musical\)")_ debuted at
Mandalay Bay's 1999 grand opening and ran for one year.[27][28] _Storm_ , an
original production show featuring Latin music, ran from April 2001 to July
2002.[29][30][31][32] _[Mamma Mia!](/wiki/Mamma_Mia! "Mamma Mia!")_ was a
long-running stage production at the resort from 2003 to 2009.[33][34] The
show was replaced with Disney's _[The Lion
King](/wiki/The_Lion_King_\(musical\) "The Lion King \(musical\)")_ , which
opened on May 15, 2009. Its run ended in 2011 to make way for _[Michael
Jackson: One](/wiki/Michael_Jackson:_One "Michael Jackson: One")_ , by [Cirque
du Soleil](/wiki/Cirque_du_Soleil "Cirque du Soleil"), which opened May
2013.[35]

Another popular attraction is the [House of Blues](/wiki/House_of_Blues "House
of Blues"), a venue for live music and a restaurant, with a capacity of
approximately 1,800. On the top floor of the hotel is the House of Blues
Foundation Room, featuring a dining room, private dining rooms, and a balcony
looking down the [Las Vegas Strip](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Strip "Las Vegas Strip").

### Mandalay
Beach[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mandalay_Bay&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Mandalay Beach")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Mandalay_Bay%2C_Las_Vegas.jpg/300px-
Mandalay_Bay%2C_Las_Vegas.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mandalay_Bay,_Las_Vegas.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mandalay_Bay,_Las_Vegas.jpg "Enlarge")

Mandalay Bay pool.

Mandalay Beach is an 11 acres (4.5 ha) pool area with three heated pools, a
[wave pool](/wiki/Wave_pool "Wave pool") with connecting pool for small
children, and a [lazy river](/wiki/Lazy_river "Lazy river") that features a
small [waterfall](/wiki/Waterfall "Waterfall"). The wave pool features 1.6
million gallons of water and waves in 90-second intervals with heights ranging
anywhere from two to four feet. Because of this, it has a strict 48" height
requirement. The European-style pool, called Moorea, features its own private
bar as well as the allowance of female guests to bathe topless. Because of
this, Moorea is separated from the rest of the pool by [smoked
glass](/wiki/Smoked_glass "Smoked glass") windows and has an over-21
requirement. There are also two restaurants at the Beach. The pool area won
the _Las Vegas Review Journal_ 's Reader's "Best Pool of Las Vegas" award for
seven years in a row.[36] One pool remains open throughout the winter months.

In keeping with the resort's tropical theme, it features a [saltwater
aquarium](/wiki/Saltwater_aquarium "Saltwater aquarium"), the [Shark Reef
Aquarium](/wiki/Shark_Reef_at_Mandalay_Bay "Shark Reef at Mandalay Bay"),
which contains the third largest tank in North America. Shark Reef Aquarium
contains numerous other exhibits, including two tunnel-shaped, walk-through
aquariums.

### Mandalay Bay Events
Center[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mandalay_Bay&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Mandalay Bay Events Center")]

Main article: [Mandalay Bay Events Center](/wiki/Mandalay_Bay_Events_Center
"Mandalay Bay Events Center")

The Mandalay Bay Events Center, a 12,000-seat arena, hosts major events
including concerts, [boxing](/wiki/Boxing "Boxing") matches, and [Ultimate
Fighting Championship](/wiki/Ultimate_Fighting_Championship "Ultimate Fighting
Championship") events. It has played host to the [Latin Grammy
Awards](/wiki/Latin_Grammy_Awards "Latin Grammy Awards") several times, and
the [Miss Universe](/wiki/Miss_Universe "Miss Universe") pageant.

### Mandalay Bay Convention
Center[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mandalay_Bay&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Mandalay Bay Convention Center")]

Main article: [Mandalay Bay Convention
Center](/wiki/Mandalay_Bay_Convention_Center "Mandalay Bay Convention Center")

This 1,000,000 square feet (93,000 m2) facility is one of the largest
privately owned convention centers in the world. It has several ballrooms
ranging in size up to 100,000 square feet (9,300 m2), and can support up to 75
breakout sessions.

### The Shoppes at Mandalay
Place[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mandalay_Bay&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: The Shoppes at Mandalay Place")]

The Shoppes at Mandalay Place is a 310-foot (94 m)- long retail sky
bridge.[37][38]
